utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Hi, I'm Greg Gutfeld with Kimberly Guilfoyle, Juan Williams, Jesse Watters, and she thinks the marble that she lives on is black, Dana Perino -- "The Five." Recently, CNN asked, with all the good news, why aren't people smiling? It's like the local skunk wondering why everything around him stinks. Their cluelessness results from a complete denial of how Donald Trump works, fueled by a confirmation bias that seeks only to prove their negative point. Take North Korea. Just months ago, it was nuclear war.

utterances.speaker: WOLF BLITZER, CNN
utterances.utterance: Trump's fury. The president is warning he'll respond to North Korea talks with a fire and power that the world has never seen. Will the war of words escalate into an actual nuclear war?

utterances.speaker: JEFFREY TOOBIN, CNN LEGAL ANALYST
utterances.utterance: What he actually said is if there's going to be more threats, not an attack, but more threats from North Korea, we're going to see in effect a nuclear war.

utterances.speaker: LAWRENCE O'DONNELL, MSNBC
utterances.utterance: The president of the United States today threatened nuclear war.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That did not age well, nor should it. We can't let the press forget it either, especially as Trump heads historic meeting with an unpredictable man with a strange haircut. But enough about Rodman. Rocket Man, months ago, he was Dr. Evil, and now he's at the table. It reminds me of a sitcom from the '90s.

utterances.speaker: PRESIDENT DONALD TRUMP
utterances.utterance: So, we'll see what happens. We'll see what happens. Let's see what happens. We'll see what happens. So, we'll see what happens. We'll see what happens.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, God. Now, before you say Kim wins by inclusion, isn't that how diplomacy works? You know, meet with the guy, talk to him? It's funny, dialogue used to be the left's safe word. We're always being told we need a national conversation about stuff. So here's an international conversation. Yet, the same dopes who condemn Trump's fire and fury now chide the opposite. Maybe if Trump says he's dialoguing with Kim, CNN can avoid another crying jag. The good news we've gone from fretting over war to debating the hotel bill. How can the press miss this? Well, they hate the guy, Trump, that is. They're so married to safe, predictable politicians whose main risk involves choosing the red tie for the fundraiser. Trump runs circles around them because in his world, he has to. I've said it before: Kim may be a dictator, but Trump is a developer from Queens. I'm not sure what's scarier. All right, I guess I should break the news here that I am going to Singapore.

utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Are you aware of that?

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, no. I don't have my credentials yet.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: How are you going to do on the plane?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'm going to do great. I'm going to do great. Just -- you know, Gorka is going. So, if Gorka is going, I think I should be able to go, right?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I actually believe you that you.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: God help whoever is flying next to you on any flight.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Live version of the G.G. Show from Singapore?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Why shouldn't one of us be able to go?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I mean, Watters' World should definitely go.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You with diamond and silk in Singapore.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: And Rodman.

utterances.speaker: JUAN WILLIAMS, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Lord have mercy.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: The thing about -- that intro, you know, it was so ridiculous, you know. It's like a 70's show, right?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But the thing is that's the world we're living in.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah, it is.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I mean, Dennis Rodman?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Come on, man. This is ridiculous. Now, you're approaching the point where you say this isn't -- this is absurdity. This is like some -- something -- somebody dreamed up a play and you say that play -- nobody is going to believe that. That jumped the shark long time ago.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But, you know, to your point, this is something that hasn't happened before and maybe that's why it's happening, Dana. They took a salesman from Queens like -- the process, you always look at this like a process. Buying a house or renovating a property. Could you say that that's how he's looking at this?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Maybe. But I also think that one of the reasons it's happening as well is that the Kim family, Kim Jong-un being the ultimate one, he -- they got the nuclear weapon.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: So, now they feel like they're equals. They feel like they have an ability to come to the table and actually negotiate. The sticking point about denuclearization, what does it really mean and how it all works? I would say cautiously optimistic.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Not necessarily a cynic or skeptic on it. I do hope that it works. But, I also know that we're dealing with the North Koreans.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I thought it was just dopes like me who were skeptical.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, everybody is.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: The show is called, we'll see what happens.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: That's the whole point.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But, Greg is like defending the president as just a salesman from Queens. He's just a guy from Queens. Now, the Democrats' argument would be, oh, wait a second. Don't we usually have people who have mastered foreign affairs and diplomacy involved. And they've decided, believe me, there were previous offers from the Kim family, the grandfather, father, and now him, for meetings but everybody said no because we're not giving you that. And you said that was dopey and old- school.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know what Trump is? He's like The Blair Witch Project. After that movie came out, all other movies changed.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: With the horrible camerawork.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, the horrible -- I was terrified. I want to respond to Juan's misguided belief that we should be doing the same thing.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I didn't say the same thing because, obviously.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: You mean the failed diplomacy of the past?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: . as Dana said, the man has nukes now. He didn't have nukes before.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: How that happen?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: All right. So, here's the thing. People get upset, they think, oh, Rodman is like a sideshow. He's obviously not going to have any place in the negotiations. This is going to be President Trump with Kim Jong-un. If Kim Jong-un feels more comfortable like no one is out to kill him, with his friend for life, Dennis Rodman there, fine. Give him his security blanket, OK.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah, yeah.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Let him have him there. It will be fine. Who cares? That's the bottom line. Ultimately, if the goal gets achieved and they accomplish something and they're to denuclearize, would anybody really care whether Dennis Rodman was in the country at the time or not? I'm about the results and getting -- and moving on target and getting to the finish line there. So, if that's some kind of peculiar thing that makes him feel more comfortable that isn't some kind, like, you know, assassination plot on him or something.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: . and he's like OK, I'm going to be safe, my buddy. He's been there six times to North Korea.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: How many people could say that?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's a great point. You remember when the left sent James Taylor over to Europe for diplomacy and they thought that was brilliant? And so, Trump sends Rodman and he gets beat up for that. I mean, I don't see what the difference is. Like, Kimberly's point is exactly correct. He's met little rocket man more than any other American on the face of the earth. They've done karaoke together. They've gone skiing together. They played ping-pong together, basketball. Listen to the things he said about Dennis Rodman. He says he's like a little kid who doesn't want more. He thinks Americans are going to try to take over the country, so he wants to nuke up and he feels like that's his only defense. He wants to help his culture improved. And he loves America. They said when he went over there, he played the soundtrack of Dallas? And. GUILFOYLE: He's like Greg.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah. And Rocky all day, for four hours straight, he plays those theme songs. He likes The Doors.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: So, he's insane.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He likes The Doors and he like Jimi Hendrix. But, to your point about real estate, he's like a motivated buyer.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He really wants his countries to succeed and he really wants -- he wants money and Trump wants to help this guy out. So, he brings him to this five-star luxury resort where it's like $3,500 tasting menu, peacocks roaming around. He's got this like east meets west deal. It's a $6,000 presidential suite. He's saying, listen, capitalism could be good if you do the right thing.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah, yeah, exactly.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: And now he's read "Art of the Deal," which was.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's an old sales tactic that you have the client thinking they have something to lose that they already have. So, they've gotten this far and they don't, you know -- and I've said this before, Giuliani, you know, was talking about North Korea and he says that he's got North Korea on its knees. These are the things you shouldn't be saying.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's not necessary.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, Giuliani, stop.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Say that in private dinner party.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: . not on television.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You wanted to feel like a win-win even if it not might be.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right, I agree.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know the real person we should be talking about going, John Bolton.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Is he going?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes. And I think.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: . travel in first class.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Separately.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: With extra leg room, yeah.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: It's no6t personal. But, anyway, I think he's the one that scares Kim Jong-un.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: . right?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I agree.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And the reason is, because, as Jesse was alluding to that someone is going to take him out, and what happens to Gaddafi when we made the Libya.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That was the problem when Bolton said that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Right, it was a problem. But -- the contingent on part of that is, oh, wait a second, I think Bolton was a big opponent of the Iran deal. You know, ideally, if we had the best possible outcome from what happens, you know what, it would be the North Korean deal along the lines of the Iran deal when Bolton is an opponent there.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, you mean, where you can self-inspect your own nuclear facilities?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You want the North Koreans.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You go on with that bogus argument. The fact is.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So, you want to have a thing.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: . $6 billion in cash. That's what you want to do, Juan?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Even the Trump administration certified the deal. So, I'm just saying, you know -- I think what's happened here, by the way, is we just go back and say, oh, yeah, the Korean war is over, we're going to try to be friends. This is the start of the process. I think the president said much the same.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah, he could be right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: We'll see what happen.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: The one thing though -- breaking news today about -- was it A.P.? President Obama fudging about the Iran.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes. So, apparently the Obama administration led the Iranians to skirt all of these financial sanctions to give them access to like billions of dollars of hard American currency. That -- no one knew that. They had to get a lawsuit from, I believe, judicial watch to find that out. Then the A.P. reported it. So, the Obama administration, to make it easier for the Iranians, largest state sponsor of terror, to get cash behind the worlds back and that's not a scandal?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: It's not a scandal.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Not a scandal.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I'm saying on this one, you knew that the whole idea was to give them the money that we had frozen. It was their money in the first place. And then, secondly.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Their money, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: . to try -- it was their money. Secondly, to try to reintegrate them into the global economic structure.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So why did they hide that?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Because, just your reaction.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Oh, because they didn't want mean Watters to react that way?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: They don't want people to go hyperbolic over something.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Because it's something to get upset about.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Dana?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I'm just going to say, it's not only that the Obama administration actually went to a couple of American banks and tried to ask them to do this, it's not money-laundering but it kind of feels like that, which is basically saying make this money right, and the banks refused.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So, you're saying bankers have higher ethical standards than the Obama administration?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It was about concern that they would be penalized.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Correct.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: . because of it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Kimberly, last word. How do you think the media is going to cover this?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Sensational. They're going to try and make some jokes about it because of Dennis Rodman, like they have. But, nevertheless, I think the outcome of it is going to speak for itself, you know, in terms of being result oriented. He's going to do what he does. He's able to work a deal. He's able to now go and meet with Kim Jong-un when no one else was able to get him to the table. Think about that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Exactly. You know what I found in the green room? I found this book in the green room it's by -- it's Newt Gingrich's book.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Oh, that's my copy.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, no, to Steve Doocy, a great guy -- a great guy who's been a friend in the morning and Steve left it in there.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Oh.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah, some friend. Now I've got a free book.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: What is wrong with you?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Steve, never leave a book in the green room. More positive economic news pouring in for the president, what it means for the midterms, next.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: More positive economic news for the Trump administration ahead of the midterms. For the first time ever, there are more job openings in the U.S. than there are people who are unemployed. Trump's campaign manager is touting the president's accomplishments as a springboard to the upcoming election. BRAD PARSCALE, 2020 TRUMP CAMPAIGN MANAGER: The data has never looked better for the president. I don't say that and people's articles are written that I say just to make them happy. It's just not true. I mean, we've run the largest state operation survey work in the country, and we see that America is starting to see that their personal economies are getting better. National security is getting better, the things that are around happening. And I think they're starting to see these accomplishments. As much as the media doesn't want outside of a couple stations or a couple of people, how much they don't want to talk about accomplishments, they're starting to get through.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: On the other side of the political aisle, outgoing Starbucks executive chairman Howard Schultz is calling out Democrats for going too far left.

utterances.speaker: HOWARD SCHULTZ, OUTGOING STARBUCKS EXECUTIVE CHAIRMAN
utterances.utterance: I ask myself, how are we going to pay for all these things in terms of things like single- payer or people espousing the fact that the government is going to give everyone a job. I don't think that's realistic. And I think we've got to get away from all these falsehoods and start talking about the truth and not false promises.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: So, it's always better, Jesse, to run on accomplishments than aspirations because then you say, well, look, the proof is in the pudding. We have it right here. What do you think of that?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah. I mean, the Trump administration is going to run strong on the economy in 2020, and he's got the wind at his back. The New York Times had a headline the other day, it said, we ran out of words to describe how good the job numbers are. That is from the New York Times.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Is that not fake news?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's when it's not fake news. No, when it's not good that's when it's fake news.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And I think the president feels very confident about it. So, there's a lot of distractions out there with the kneeling or, you know, with the twitter stuff. But, when you look at your personal economy, and that's what Brad's done because he has the line on all these Americans through all these sophisticated data instruments that they have still left over from the election. Wages are going up and they're going up for the first time since 2000. And they're going up for all Americans, because when you have such a tight job market like that competition for jobs increases and then you have to pay people more because there's more competition for better workers. And I think that's just going to keep going.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Actually, it's a little bit slow. I think, you know, companies ought to be doing more, I think.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, because I don't think.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, like this company.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But I don't think wages are going up.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Wages are not going up?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's fake news.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: They're up.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: The wages are not going up.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Three percent.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: . in the way that people think they should be. And, guess what, labor participation. Labor participation. Remember, you guys used to go on and on about, oh, Obama, he has an unemployment numbers good, but look at labor -- well, look at labor participation now you folks, it's terrible.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Wait, labor participation?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Basically -- if Bob Beckel were here, because we've been having this debate for years, he would say that's because there are so many people retiring.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: . it's not Obama's fault.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Like, 90 million Americans who are not.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's the thing that you're going to take out.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, no. The big one for me was.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Give him credit, Juan. It's good economy.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I give Obama credits. I give Trump credit for continuing Obama's policies.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, there it is.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But I would say that if you're talking about real change for someone at home, I think that's what Howard Schultz was talking about, making a difference in people's lives, then you're talking about, are you getting more pay? Answer?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But, or is your pay getting eaten up by other things? Kimberly, I think California, one of the big primary issues yesterday was that there was a proposal on the table for an additional gas tax in California, and that went over like a lead balloon there. That actually -- that state senator got recalled because people are looking at the economy and saying no, we're not going to be doing that.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: California is doing amazing. I mean, do you want the rest of the country to be like that, Juan? I don't think so. So, now, taking one shower a week. The tax on your pool. You'll get taxed right out of your house into an apartment, like a one bedroom. Yeah, you can't drive your car, so then you can't get to work. So, I mean, it's so badly mismanaged in terms of the idea, people waking up to it. But, guess what, like, when you have something like this, an economy that's booming, and you have people, they're saying, well, these are jobs that we can actually sustain our families with, that we can actually put kids in school, and lunches together, and be able to put dinner on the table and gas in the car, that's what Americans can feel and relate to. And that's why the president is in such a good position. It's very favorable right now in terms of looking forward on the economic predictors and indicators for midterms and for reelection, whether Democrats like it or not. Look, Bill Clinton had some good economic numbers as well. It was able to.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And he got right through impeachment.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Pull him right over the top.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Certainly not forecasting anything. So, what do you think about what Howard Schultz was saying? Is this a Democrat who -- he says he's not thinking about 2020, or maybe he will, maybe he won't. I think he's definitely running. Is this something that the Democrats need, someone to pour cold water on their ideas?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah, because right now -- I mean, to Kimberly's point, I mean, America is this great beautiful restored house on the hill except there's one room that is rotten.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: . and it's California. And why is it rotten? It's a combination of spending and identity politics. And a fear of dealing with the problems that they have that Schultz is talking about. As a California boy and you're a California girl, you keep wondering, what is it going to take? Here's why nothing is happening in California. The rich liberals are safe. They got their real estate, and it's behind a gate. Meanwhile, it's a real-life dystopia everywhere else. It really is like the set of Mad Max. You have tense all over the street. You have deprecating hordes. You have disease spreading. I'm not going to get into that again.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Please.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Garbage trucks accidentally almost throwing people away. I mean, this is like -- it's like.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: . Soylent Green going on there. And so, what you're talking about, here's a country that's run -- here's a state run by liberals. It's the worst kind of economic inequality. And all you've got to do is look at that and I think that's what Schultz is probably getting at. It's like you can see the end result right there. It's a problem. This is a big deal. And it ain't going to be solved with progressive politics.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: He's trying to be the Donald Trump of the left, who provide a different, sort of, Democrat, populist movement.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And we've seen that in Seattle too.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah, yeah, yeah. Any businessman knows this is going to destroy.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That's why California, I think, is like -- would be the third biggest economy in the world.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Imagine if it's managed well.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Here's the threat to what you're talking about, which is the trade wars. And that's what even Republicans have trouble with Trump on this trade policy.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I agree.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And that big threat to all your.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: California is about economic inequality among the very rich and everybody else.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And China just responded to those tariffs and they've said we're going to buy $70 billion.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: We'll see what goes. But, you know, Canada.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: We'll see.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: The new show, we'll see what happens.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: By the way, there's more jobs available than available workers. They need it -- they need -- the work websites have to act like dating websites now or dating apps.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Like, it's .

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Or you're going to have to look at immigration.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right, three former top Obama officials facing new scrutiny for their conduct in the Clinton email investigation. We have details next.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Big new developments involving three former top Obama officials. According to a report the Justice Department inspector general is concluding former FBI Director James Comey defied his authority at times. The I.G. also reportedly set to criticize former Attorney General Loretta Lynch over her handling of the Clinton email investigation, including her tarmac meeting with Bill Clinton. Meanwhile, fired FBI Deputy Director Andrew McCabe is asking for immunity in exchange for his congressional testimony about the Clinton email probe. Can you believe that? So, Jesse, you know, as a former prosecutor, I'm thinking to myself, he's looking for immunity because.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He's got something.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yeah, this is the problem. So, why not take it forward, have it prosecuted for it instead of.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right. A lot of people are saying why not just give it to him? And, you know, make him maybe flip on Comey. What does he know? Does he know anything about Loretta, about slippery James? I mean, Dana has been saying all week this is bigger than Watergate, and I completely agree.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes, she said it a lot.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: But we're talking -- here's one thing and we'll find out what he knows. And maybe we can do that through the threat of prosecution or not. But the leak of the I.G. report -- I mean, that's just a big leak. I mean, that is a pretty big leak. And so, people are coming out and saying I've seen it. This is what's in it. So, I don't know what to trust about the leak. We're saying, you know, Comey was insubordinate and he did what he did. He marched to the beat of his own drum. He did what he did with Loretta, and kind of big footed her and made the announcement behind her back. And then he came out a week before the election and did the whole thing with the e-mails and Weiner. We kind of knew that already. It's about whether or not there's going to be a criminal referral. And if this is it, OK. We kind of knew that already. I think there's more that we're going to see from the I.G. report. And there's still going to be another I.G. report about the abuses under FISA with then-candidate Trump.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Can I -- can I jump in and say you're right? And I rarely say that to you, but I think where's the beef on this?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I must be wrong if you're agreeing with me.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Where's the beef? You know, Trump has been pumping out the release of this I.G. report from the Department of Justice inspector general Michael Horowitz. He's saying, "Oh, this is going to be terrible, because it's going to undermine not only Comey's credibility but the Mueller probe." Here's the leak. I don't know if the leak is complete, comprehensive.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, we don't know.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But what we know so far would lead me to say this ain't much, folks. This is -- if anything, this report supports Hillary Clinton's complaint that, in fact, Mueller [SIC] was out to get her -- Comey was out to get her.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well, the reason why Comey was out to get her was to make sure that, when she won, there would be no questions. Right? Wasn't that the whole point? He was trying to do her a favor because he wanted her to win, because he was a partisan hack. This is not just bigger than Watergate. It's bigger than "Watters' World."

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Oh, my gosh.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's huge.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It is huge.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I respectfully disagree.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I love the idea of immunity, but it's used incorrectly. It's used in court. Immunity should be able to be used at your workplace, on Twitter, in relationships.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Like, why is it just in court? People use immunity in court so that you can screw over some other person. It's like, "I'm going to give Jesse immunity" so you would narc on Dana.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: We should be able to do that at work.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I would have nothing to narc on Dana for, because she's squeaky clean.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Squeaky. We can hear her from over here. So Dana, obviously, McCabe has issues because of the previous I.G. report saying that he lied to the FBI, so he wants immunity here. I don't believe that the Senate will do that for him.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, also, what happens with an inspector general report is they come up with the report, and then, if you are named in it, you get a chance to look at it. And so that, I think, is why we have the leaks. Is because these people, who -- I don't know who leaked it. But now several people have probably had a chance to look at it. Their lawyers have looked at it. And so what happens is, in a government investigation, one of the things that they can do, if you've left government, there's not that much the I.G. can do, but they have access to all of the government's devices of texts and emails. So that can be quite deadly for somebody in this situation. They also, because this has become so partisan, McCabe might think, "I'm going to ask for immunity, because no matter what I say, these Republicans are going to have come after me to protect President Trump." And vice versa. Loretta Lynch might think the same thing, et cetera. So --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Before we go, we should note that last week we were all heavy into Spygate. And now you have not only Trey Gowdy but Speaker Ryan saying, "Hmm. Nothing there."

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And Senator Burr.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So I mean, I don't know.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It was fun while it lasted.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Not over yet. Not over yet. Wait till 9 o'clock.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Actually -- there is actually something there. I mean, you can laugh about it, but there is something there.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, yes? What?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And they hadn't seen any of those documents when they were saying that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Informants.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Everything was proper. They didn't see the documents.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I see.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Look at Juan. Just took the wind right out of his sails with that. All right. President Trump blasting the media for speculating about the first lady and what he is saying ahead. Stay with us.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: First lady Melania Trump appearing with the president today amid wild media speculation. President Trump ripping the press for spreading rumors on Twitter: "The fake news media has been so unfair, and vicious, to my wife and our great first lady, Melania. During her recovery from surgery they reported everything from near death, to facelift, to left the W.H. (and me) for N.Y. or Virginia, to abuse. All fake, she is doing really well!" Greg, so we talked about this the other day. Melania is back. How humiliating was this for them?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't think they can see that they're humiliated.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They're in a bubble of confirmation bias. They can spin it any way they want. I do have a new narrative for Brian Stelter. He should say, on his show, "How do we know that's the real Melania? Maybe it's a body double or perhaps a hologram and she's actually in a cell in a castle underwater made of skulls." Because that's about -- but it's true. This is what cognitive dissonance does to people. They can't see how they react irrationally to every word and every story. Their myopia is malignant. And they just -- they should just -- they should step out of their bubble and see how silly and stupid they are and maybe -- maybe send some flowers. Send some flowers.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: They should be kind to her. But I must -- I can't get you, because it seems to me like Donald Trump's spread more conspiracy theories than anybody. I mean, he was -- wasn't he worried about Hillary's health? Wasn't he saying Obama wasn't born in the country? Wasn't he saying --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, Hillary's health was a concern, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, no. It wasn't any concern.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But she was running to be president.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: She collapsed --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, yes.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: -- on the ground. And the Scooby van had to come.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, yes, and I think this morning, what, over on MSNBC --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: "What about-ism is not --"

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- they went crazy because of the mention of the facelift business, right? Because guess who did that first? Donald Trump.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Was that ever disproven?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: What? You and Alex Jones.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Let's get this back on track.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But I'm just pointing -- I point out, the "what about-ism," we all get Donald Trump. We remember what he said about Ted -- Ted Cruz's dad. We get it. But you know what? This woman is, like, you know, she's just coming off surgery. And these guys acted like vultures. That's the bottom line. Right?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, I think that, like, news -- news and entertainment have melded, and they are just -- everybody is fascinated --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Not here.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: -- by this White House and by this administration. She was missing -- missing? -- for 26 days. It wasn't like it was 26 months or something like that. The bigger story of the missing person to me is the crown prince in Saudi Arabia. I'd love to know more about that. They were at the -- FEMA to get a briefing on the hurricane. And, like, the entire cabinet is there. That's how seriously they're taking hurricane prep. That was the bigger headline out of that.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes, I think the media is just totally out of line with this. And in particular, I know, Dana, you talked about this earlier on your program. Talking about abuse --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: -- suggesting that the president had abused her.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: That she was in hiding. So the fact that he stood up for her and that he addressed this, I like that. He should have come out and said that, and I think it was smart that he did. It's good to stick up for his wife and for the first lady who's done an incredible job for the country. My gosh. She's not allowed to recover, recuperate from a surgery? I mean, what is wrong with everybody? They should be showing some respect and giving her some privacy like they would if it was Michelle Obama or, you know, any other first lady that serves the country. She's back. She's doing well and that's that. It just makes them look really foolish.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And these were not little Twitter people --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- that had no name. These were legitimate reporters.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: -- conservative.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes. So now I'm glad we put that --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Are you going to do your thing? "Woke 'em up." (ph)

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: "Woke 'em up." (ph)

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: President Clinton tries to walk back his controversial Monica Lewinsky comments, next.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: A do-over for Bill Clinton. After receiving backlash for appearing insensitive to Monica Lewinsky in a sit-down interview with NBC earlier this week, the former president took a second shot at clarifying his remarks.

utterances.speaker: BILL CLINTON, FORMER PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.utterance: When I saw the interview, I thought that, because they had to, you know, distill it, and it looked like I was saying I didn't apologize, and I had no intention to. And I was mad at me. It wasn't my finest hour.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: "Not my finest hour"? What do you say, Dana?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I think that that is good and appropriate, and I also think it sounds like somebody in the communications team got a hold of him and said, "This would be a good thing to say," and he said it. And so OK. I don't know if it resolves anything.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Nothing sincere?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No, I think that's one of the things that Bill Clinton has always had. Right? Is that even if he's saying a line that he's been given, that people think that he feels their pain. The sincerity quotient was actually quite high with him.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK. So Kimberly, one of the things he said that got some attention was that the interviewer, he said he got offended with the interviewer, without realizing that the young man --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- who's Craig Melvin, is young enough to be his son. Was that blaming the interviewer or was that legit?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: No, that was his initial reaction, was, "Oh, I was offended sort of by the nature of the question," him asking it. Look, it was a fair question. I think the young man conducted a good interview. Bill Clinton is showing contrition now. He's very good at being believable and saying, "OK, this is how I think, and this is how I feel." I'm sure he did get backlash about it. I'm sure that yes, comms team members were, like, "Listen, you've got to clean this up, because you've just, like, huge mess in aisle seven right now, and everybody is upset with you." So it was an unforced error, but he is good at sort of trying to make it, you know, better. Still, you know, it was something that he should have thought about, and he shouldn't have reacted that way. It kind of -- that was, like, his truest voice about it in terms of being offended, that he felt he was a victim, that he left the White House in debt for $16 million. Those are not relatable, you know, comments. He's lucky that Hillary is not running again.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Also, is he 70? I mean, most reporters in America could be his offspring, from the age group standpoint.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Who knows?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Oh, gosh. I think you're like -- wow.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You know what I mean.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, we know what you mean. Anyway --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I don't know how old Craig Melvin is but if you're 70, then, like, most people could be your children.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Remember, Greg?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think he's, like, 39 or 40.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You know what I mean?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: We get it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: We get it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And I watched the clip back, and even I was mad at me.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: All right, all right. So Jesse --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- the critical point was on the Craig Melvin thing, that Clinton said, "Hey, I did apologize, but this guy doesn't remember." And then he went on, and I think the part that got people really aggravated, especially his critics, was he said he left the White House $16 million in debt, as if that spoke to the issue. But that doesn't speak to the issue of what happened in the Oval Office with an intern.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I wish I was rich enough to be $16 million in debt. Like Kimberly said, it's just not relatable. And only a Democrat can get a do-over in the mainstream media.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, is that right?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Isn't that amazing, how he just gets to go in there.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: "If you had to say this again, what would you say, Mr. President?" I mean, come on, Colbert.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's true.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That was pretty -- that was pretty nice of you.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: It would be front page everywhere if it was -- you know.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I know. Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Teflon Don?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Teflon Don.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, please.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, he would never apologize. That's the difference.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: He would never be mad at himself.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Never.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So what do you think?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well, you know, here's the issue. No one's going to miss you if you never leave. And as long as Bill is around, no one is going to miss him. He's got to go away. And you think about the presidents, like Jimmy Carter, who went away to build home, or G.W., who paints. I'm all about helping people, and I think we need to find Bill Clinton a job that doesn't place him in the spotlight. And I was thinking, he could probably open up -- because he likes to be around people. He should open up, like, a seafood restaurant or something in New Orleans. He could have, like, the Blue Dress Special.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Oh, gosh. Blue plate. Blue plate.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: He could have a cigar bar. But he could just be there --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's how he got in trouble in the first place.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: He could hit on waitresses. He could be out. Because the problem is he's -- there's no tasteful exit for the Clintons. They just linger like a bad odor, and it's born from ambivalent selfishness. He's not thinking that every time he does these shows, he's just making it worse. Retire. You know, being on TV, being famous, it's not all it cracks up to be. Trust me.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Take a break. Open a restaurant. Have some fun. I mean, not that kind of fun, but have some fun.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He has lost a step a little bit since his days in office. He's had a few of these moments. Didn't he yell at Chris Wallace and point in his face and get all red? And then he was asked about something on the trail in a diner and he kind of snapped on an NBC reporter. He has these moments where he creates headaches for the Clinton team, and he always has to clean it up.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: He's frustrated.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: But that's what also lovable about Bill. He's so passionate, he can't control himself. He makes a mistake. Then he comes back.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Wait, sounds relatable all of a sudden.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, so relatable. You know, when he speaks, it feels like he's just speaking to me. Like I'm the only one in the room.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Pick up the tip. Pick up the tip, yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Obviously, we are in a different era from Monica, Dana, with the hashtag #MeToo and all the revelations.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So I think -- it's interesting. I'm not sure that we can honestly understand his perspective. Because this guy is plus 70. Lives in a different era.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But I think the reasons we have #MeToo, in some ways, is that it was building for 20 years.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And 20 years ago is when that whole thing went down.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think it's even longer than that.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: They helped build it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Harvey had been doing it for 20 years, and Bill Cosby had been doing it for 20 years. So you get -- the excuse can't fly.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, all right. Controversy. "One More Thing" is up next to make you laugh.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: "One More Thing" -- Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, 50 years ago today, Robert F. Kennedy was assassinated in Los Angeles. The brother of the former president, who was assassinated, John F. Kennedy, was running for president when he was killed. Today members of his family, former president Clinton and others went to Arlington National Cemetery to celebrate his life. Here's his son [SIC], Congressman Joe Kennedy III, remembering his grandfather and the love he had for his surviving wife, Ethel.

utterances.speaker: REP. JOE KENNEDY III (D), MASSACHUSETTS
utterances.utterance: His love, ever enduring of his extraordinary wife and partner, who 50 years after his passing, still wears her wedding ring.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: It's pretty emotional. There's no doubt RFK, a great American patriot, changed this country for the better.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right. Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I've got a heartwarming story you're going to love. All right? All right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'll be the judge.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: This is from San Diego. And it is Hoover High School, where food service worker Deborah Davis, affectionately called Aunt Debbie by the students, was surprised with a new reliable way to get to work. She has been working there at the school for years. She also volunteers at the food -- for homeless people out of a food shelter, volunteers in a nursing home, and she had a terrible car to get to work. So they -- the Recycled Rides and Kids for Peace bought the car, and then the students at the school fixed it up in the shop. And this is what she said.

utterances.speaker: DEBORAH DAVIS, SCHOOL FOOD SERVICE WORKER
utterances.utterance: Thank you all so much. Thank you all so much. I'm looking for my reward in heaven and you all gave me a little bit here on earth.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: So it was a fun way to end the school year there in Hoover High School and a lovely thing to do.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It just raises the question: where do you get the giant bows for cars?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Great question.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Thank you. Could somebody email me that?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Green room?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I would like to give the giant bow as a gift, but have it on the top of a car. Like, "Look at this giant bow I got you." Wouldn't that be great?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: But not the car.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, a brand-new car, come in and say, "Look, I delivered this bow."

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Sometimes they have those at the dealership when you get a car for Christmas or --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Jesse, I'm sorry.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS (singing)
utterances.utterance: Take me out to the ball game.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: She drinks it?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: She takes the ball there, and down the hatch. She chugs it. Of course, you've got to chug the beer if it lands in your cup.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Every man's dream.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's why I don't go to baseball games.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That's why you don't got to baseball games?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I'm afraid I'm going to get hit in the head.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, they've extended the nets.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Nice form.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That was better than the softball play from yesterday.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, no. That was pretty good. That's fun. I loved that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Kimberly.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Mine is in the cute and adorable category, although that was pretty impressive, that catch. OK. So you like Golden Retrievers, Dana?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: All right. OK.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Are they a dog?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: So Golden Retrievers -- they're a dog -- helped this cute, cute little toddler escape from room at night. Now, she's 15 months old. Her name is Chloe, and she's been escaping from her bedroom in the middle of the night. Right? And so her parents were like, what is going on? How is she getting out? So these little two pet Golden Retrievers would actually open the door, like help her get out because then she feeds them treats.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Oh, my gosh.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: They were like, "Here we go. Let's break her out. And she'll feed us."

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Those dogs are smart.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I mean, how smart are these dogs? Like we got away.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: How'd you find that

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: In the middle -- Quenette found it for me. It's very good. Isn't this adorable, though?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Oh, my God.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Very cute.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: And then she feeds them. They're happy. Like, "See you tomorrow night."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right. I have -- my new FOX News podcast is up. It's with Robert Cialdini. He's the author of "Influence and Persuasion." He's considered by many people to be the Godzilla of persuasion. You read any of his books, it changes the way you think about stuff. But first, time for this.

utterances.speaker: GRAPHIC
utterances.utterance: Greg's Disgusting News

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: "Greg's Disgusting News." Avert your eyes to this horrible, horrible video. It looks to me like a cute hedgehog napping on a stuffed animal, and I think it's disgusting.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Getting a little cuddle.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's terrible. It's terrible. Look at that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's cute.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's pretty cute.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, I see that. It looks a little like Kilmeade.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think he has a Greg haircut.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, it's more like Kilmeade. You can check out the hair plugs.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Oh, my God!

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Kilmeade's hair plugs.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: You're getting so mean.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Kilmeade and Doocy hate you now.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know what? Feeling's mutual. All right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, my goodness.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Get ready for your news canon. Her name is Shannon. Shannon Bream.

utterances.speaker: SHANNON BREAM, FOX NEWS
utterances.utterance: Listen, your distaste for cute, fluffy things is disturbing. You might want to get some counseling. Greg, thank you.
